item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Tiananmen Square, the Police Leap Into Action
item.description: The police appear to be seizing anyone raising a sign in public, no matter what it says.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Didi Kirsten Tatlow/The New York Times
item.media:description: A man who appeared to be a protester was seized by the police in Beijing on Friday.

item.title: World Briefing: Myanmar: Opposition Leader’s Strategy
item.description: If the Nov. 8 vote is credible, most observers believe that Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s party, the National League for Democracy, will win the most seats in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: For Afghans in Kunduz, Taliban Assault Is Just the Latest Affront
item.description: For years, residents of the strategic northern province have been at the mercy of corrupt or inept government and an abusive police force.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Afghan forces at a checkpoint in Kunduz on Wednesday as a soldier, left in background, appeared to raise the national flag.

item.title: Obama Issues U.S. Apology Over Bombing of Doctors Without Borders Hospital in Afghanistan
item.description: Five days after the U.S. bombed an Afghan hospital, the president’s personal apology appeared to do little to satisfy the leader of the doctors group.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Dr. Joanne Liu, the president of Doctors without Borders, spoke on Wednesday in Geneva.

item.title: Russian Cruise Missiles Help Syrians Go on the Offensive
item.description: The Russian-backed ground offensive followed a missile assault, reflecting what one official called a new phase of the Syria alliance.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: - Russian Defense Ministry , via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Moscow said it had fired 26 missiles from the Caspian Sea.

item.title: U.S. Indicts Members of Powerful Honduran Family
item.description: Jaime Rolando Rosenthal, Honduras’s vice president in the 1980s and one of its wealthiest men, is among those facing money laundering charges.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Yemen Airsrike Said to Kill 23 at a Wedding
item.description: The attack was the second airstrike on a wedding in Yemen in a little over a week, and it added to growing criticism over the coalition’s air campaign.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Putin’s Birthday Gift: N.H.L. Teammates and a Victory
item.description: The Russian president celebrated his 63rd birthday by scoring seven goals during a hockey match that was broadcast live on national TV.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry Awarded to Tomas Lindahl, Paul Modrich and Aziz Sancar for DNA Studies
item.description: This week’s three Nobels reflect the globalization of science, which in the last century the United States often dominated.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.media:credit: Christine T. Nguyen/The Herald-Sun, via Associated Press

item.title: World Briefing: Zimbabwe: Elephants Poisoned at Park
item.description: Five people were in police custody and were being questioned over the killing of 11 elephants.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: No New Ebola Cases Were Reported in the Past Week, Health Agency Says
item.description: The World Health Organization has warned that Ebola could still come back because more than 500 people in Guinea who may have been exposed are still being monitored.
item.dc:creator: DENISE GRADY

item.title: World Briefing: Greece: Premier Alex Tsipras Wins Confidence Vote
item.description: As expected, all 155 lawmakers in the governing coalition in the 300-member Parliament backed Mr. Tsipras.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Blasts Kill at Least 18 People
item.description: Suicide bombers killed at least 18 people in three dawn attacks, including in a mosque in the northeastern town of Damaturu.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Calling Protesters in Chile ‘Dumb,’ Pope Francis Sets Off Uproar
item.description: A comment by Francis regarding a Chilean bishop accused of being complicit in clerical sexual abuse has raised doubts about the pope’s commitment to protecting victims.
item.category: Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: A Semantic Downgrade for U.S.-Russian Talks About Operations in Syria
item.description: The Pentagon dropped “deconfliction” from its lexicon, and rejected the notion that the United States and Russia were coordinating their side-by-side military efforts in Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: A Russian Sukhoi SU-30 SM jet fighter on a runway at the Hmeimim airbase on Saturday in the Syrian province of Latakia.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Canada Knows How to Respond to a Refugee Crisis
item.description: Rather than wait for refugees to risk their lives by making dangerous crossings, our diplomats must go to crisis zones to help them.
item.dc:creator: ADRIENNE CLARKSON
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A pro-refugee rally in Vancouver last month.

item.title: Angela Merkel Calls for United Europe to Address Migrant Crisis
item.description: Speaking before the European Parliament in Strasbourg, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany urged other leaders to meet “a test of historic dimensions.”
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and BARBARA SURK

item.title: U.S. Commerce Chief Makes a Pitch in Cuba
item.description: Commerce Secretary Penny Pritzker’s visit highlights the obstacles to the opening of relations with Havana championed by the Obama administration.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Violence Spreads in Israel, Despite Security Crackdown
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu canceled a trip to Germany planned for Thursday as attacks against Israelis were reported beyond Jerusalem and the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Open Source: Hungarian Fashion Photographer Defends ‘Migrant Chic’ Spread
item.description: Despite his best efforts to explain, a Hungarian photographer has been urged by many on social networks to stop trying to make “migrant chic” happen.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot from the website of Norbert Baksa, a Hungarian photographer, showing a model playing a migrant taking a selfie.
